docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, July 12 -- Eight countries came out today in support of a move to extend the life of the United Nations Little Assembly for an indefinite term.

docs.snippet: TOKYO, July 15 -- Under trade agreements between Japan and Latin American countries, now about to be signed, between 60 and 65 per cent of Japan's exports will be machinery and only 30 per cent textiles. Pre-war proportions were 7 per cent for the...
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 15 -- Under trade agreements between Japan and Latin American countries, now about to be signed, between 60 and 65 per cent of Japan's exports will be machinery and only 30 per cent textiles. Pre-war proportions were 7 per cent for the former and 50 per cent for the latter.
docs.abstract: Latin Amer nations to increase machinery imports under new pact

headline.main: LATIN AMERICA TO GET JAPANESE MACHINERY

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: QUITO, Ecuador, July 16 (UP) -The Inter-American Press Congress voted today to request the Governments of American republics that have closed newspapers to "afford ample guarantees for their reappearance."
docs.lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador, July 16 (UP) -The Inter-American Press Congress voted today to request the Governments of American republics that have closed newspapers to "afford ample guarantees for their reappearance."

headline.main: U. S. PRESS LAUDED AT QUITO CONGRESS; News Declared Free in Only 5 American Nations -- Banned Papers' Reopening Urged

docs.snippet: An increase of more than ten million tons of shipping at the Port of New York in the fiscal year ended June 30 over a comparable pre-war period was noted yesterday in vessel entrance and clearance figures released by Harry M. Durning, Collector of...
docs.lead_paragraph: An increase of more than ten million tons of shipping at the Port of New York in the fiscal year ended June 30 over a comparable pre-war period was noted yesterday in vessel entrance and clearance figures released by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs.
docs.abstract: Customs Collector repts port handled 66 million tons of shipping, yr ended June, 10 million above '38-39; stresses number of S Amer ships

headline.main: PORT'S SHIPPING UP BY 10,000,000 TONS; Customs Report Shows Sharp Increase Over Comparable Year Before War

docs.snippet: Quiet settled on the foreign exchanges last week and for the first time in months the market shook off the nervousness which had the probable devaluation of the pound sterling as the motivating agent. Business was in good volume, influencing a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Quiet settled on the foreign exchanges last week and for the first time in months the market shook off the nervousness which had the probable devaluation of the pound sterling as the motivating agent. Business was in good volume, influencing a general upward movement of rates.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended July 15, 1949.
